_source.body:
One day historians will look back at the period beginning with the COVID lockdowns to understand how America for over two years lost its collective mind and turned into something unrecognizable and antithetical to its founding principles.

The law is no longer blind and disinterested, but adjudicates indictment, prosecution, verdict, and punishment on the ideology of the accused.¬†

Eric Holder is held in contempt of Congress and smiles;¬†

Peter Navarro is held in contempt of Congress and is hauled off in cuffs and leg-irons.¬†

James Clapper/John Brennan lied under oath to Congress‚Äîand were rewarded with television contracts;¬†

Roger Stone did the same and a SWAT team showed up at his home.¬†

Andrew McCabe made false statements to federal investigators and was exempt.¬†

A set-up George Papadopoulos went to prison for a similar charge.¬†

So goes the new American commissariat

metadata.title: The Sovietization of American Life ‚Ä∫ American Greatness

_source.body:
By Eric Peters, CIO of One River Asset Management

‚ÄúSince central bankers are enacting monetary policy by acting like market participants, let‚Äôs analyze them like investors,‚Äù said Lindsay Politi, PM for One River‚Äôs inflation-strategy.

‚ÄúCentral banks are the biggest whale in financial market history. And we‚Äôve all seen what happens when a whale needs to exit. The catalyst is always an unaccounted risk, a surprise event, or an incorrect assumption,‚Äù said Lindsay. ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs a margin call that can‚Äôt be met, a risk officer shutting it down, or client redemptions; there‚Äôs a point where every ordinary investor is forced to liquidate.‚Äù

If the position is big enough, a bubble bursts, and risks shift from being idiosyncratic to systemic.

‚ÄúWhile global central banks were building their $31trln portfolio, there was little concern about systemic risk because they don‚Äôt have the same limitations as others.‚Äù...

‚ÄúSince central bankers are enacting monetary policy by acting like market participants, let‚Äôs analyze them like investors,‚Äù said Lindsay Politi, PM for One River‚Äôs inflation-strategy.

‚ÄúCentral banks are the biggest whale in financial market history. And we‚Äôve all seen what happens when a whale needs to exit. The catalyst is always an unaccounted risk, a surprise event, or an incorrect assumption,‚Äù said Lindsay. ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs a margin call that can‚Äôt be met, a risk officer shutting it down, or client redemptions; there‚Äôs a point where every ordinary investor is forced to liquidate.‚Äù

If the position is big enough, a bubble bursts, and risks shift from being idiosyncratic to systemic.
